commit_message:
Fix ignored [nova] service_name

The [nova] service_name parameter is supposed to be used to find
the nova endpoint from keystone catalog but in fact the parameter is
not used and has had no effect.
This change fixes the ignored parameter.

Change-Id: I00c3083d7dbcf4473af3386d114c4af9e07751a0
(cherry picked from commit 6d8fc69f94003d64e6b017218965e6867426a738)

commit_message:
Fix listener creation allowing pool protocol

Listener can be created using proxy and proxyv2 protocol which are pool
protocol and not listener protocol.

Story: 2010220
Task: 45968
Change-Id: I0b8cf3cc8dbe5bc2babc469e73e32b2ed9ccb98a
(cherry picked from commit 05b4d361721264dbb0ff9fec4bc9fa87779745a7)
(cherry picked from commit 6ae3d23e688af8b105102c8883a8e3a3228dce31)
(cherry picked from commit eeba2c2af55c40dd29095bf74ba343a963fd6c3e)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/92/878392/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - | Fixes listener creation failure when protocol used is PROXY or PROXYV2 which are pool protocol and not listener protocol.

subject: workload launch refactor to support continuous control plane test.
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-upgrade refs/changes/54/873254/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # - sanityfast: same than sanity but fails faster #IN_TEARDOWN=false FAST="" EXTERNAL_IP=$(os_cmd port show ${SRIOV_PORT} -f json -c fixed_ips | jq -r -c '.fixed_ips[0]["ip_address"]') INSTANCE_FIP=$(os_cmd floating ip create ${EXTERNAL_NET_NAME} -f json | jq -r -c '.floating_ip_address' ) if [ -z "${INSTANCE_FIP}" ]; then echo "Cannot get a new FIP" exit 66 echo "Assign FIP[${INSTANCE_FIP}] to server ${INSTANCE_NAME}" os_cmd server add floating ip ${INSTANCE_NAME} ${INSTANCE_FIP} VM_IP="${INSTANCE_FIP}"# Run openstack command with an error check. This will trigger the # cleanup_on_exit trap for sanity and sanityfast mode. This doesn't # work for command expansion - $(...) expression. function os_cmd { set -e openstack "$@" set +e } local timeout_seconds=${1:-180} IN_TEARDOWN=true local timeout_seconds=${1:-180} if [ -n "${INSTANCE_FIP}" ]; then echo "Remove ${INSTANCE_FIP} from ${INSTANCE_NAME}" openstack server remove floating ip ${INSTANCE_NAME} ${INSTANCE_FIP} grep ${INSTANCE_FIP} vm_ip.sh && rm vm_ip.sh echo "Delete floating ip ${INSTANCE_FIP}" openstack floating ip delete ${INSTANCE_FIP} fi elapsed_seconds=$((elapsed_seconds + 5)) if [ -n "${CINDER_VOL_ID}" ]; then echo "Remove cinder volume ${CINDER_VOL_ID}" openstack volume delete ${CINDER_VOL_ID} elapsed_seconds=0 while true; do openstack volume list -f value -c ID | grep -q ${CINDER_VOL_ID} if [[ ${?} -eq 1 ]]; then echo "The volume ${CINDER_VOL_ID} successfully removed" break fi sleep 5 elapsed_seconds=$((elapsed_seconds + 5 )) if [ $elapsed_seconds -ge $timeout_seconds ]; then echo "FAILURE: Failed to remove the volume ${CINDER_VOL_ID}" exit 1 fi done fi IN_TEARDOWN=false timeout_seconds=${1:-120} ssh_timeout_seconds=${1:-180} os_cmd keypair create --public-key ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub ${KEYPAIR_NAME} os_cmd flavor create --vcpus {{ workload_vcpu }} \ os_cmd router create ${TENANT_NET_NAME}_router os_cmd network create ${TENANT_NET_NAME} os_cmd subnet create \ os_cmd router add subnet ${TENANT_NET_NAME}_router ${TENANT_NET_NAME}_subnet os_cmd router set --external-gateway ${EXTERNAL_NET_NAME} ${TENANT_NET_NAME}_router os_cmd security group create ${SECGROUP_NAME} os_cmd security group rule create --proto icmp ${SECGROUP_NAME} os_cmd security group rule create --proto tcp --dst-port 22 ${SECGROUP_NAME} os_cmd security group rule create --proto tcp --dst-port 80 ${SECGROUP_NAME} os_cmd security group rule create --proto tcp --dst-port 443 ${SECGROUP_NAME} ## create sriov port os_cmd server create \ os_cmd server create \ INSTANCE_STATUS=$(os_cmd server show ${INSTANCE_NAME} -f json | jq -r '.status') elapsed_seconds=$((elapsed_seconds + 3)) CINDER_VOL_ID=$(os_cmd volume create --size 1 vol_${SUFFIX} -f json | jq -r .id) elapsed_seconds=0 if [ -n "${CINDER_VOL_ID}" ]; then echo "FAILURE: Failed to create the volume ${CINDER_VOL_ID}" exit 1 fi done else echo "FAILURE: could not create the volume." exit 65 echo "Attach volume vol_${SUFFIX} to instance ${INSTANCE_NAME}" os_cmd server add volume ${INSTANCE_NAME} ${CINDER_VOL_ID} elapsed_seconds=$((elapsed_seconds + 3)) if [ $elapsed_seconds -ge $ssh_timeout_seconds ]; then echo "Deleting ~/${INSTANCE_NAME}" rm -f "${HOME}/${INSTANCE_NAME}" fi exit $RC } trap cleanup_on_exit EXITfi if [[ "${MODE}" == "sanityfast" ]]; then FAST=10 trap cleanup_on_exit EXIT SUFFIX=$(openssl rand -hex 5) prepare_env sanity_check $FAST workload_launch $FAST $FAST

commit_message:
Fix unclear error messages in the API

Some API calls may have returned useless error messages such as

{"faultcode": "Client", "faultstring": " is not a valid option for ",
 "debuginfo": null}

when a DB constraint failed.

This commit improves the error message by reading the name of the
foreign key that failed from the exception.

The value of the parameters should have already been validated by WSME,
this exception is only thrown when there is an issue with the database
(corrupted DB, empty table or missing fields in a table).

Story 2009957
Task 44919

Change-Id: Idd6480bc0a7de7c42b34601172c2dae50077aa48
(cherry picked from commit 57e006eac321b210c98917019572b3576aefd97e)
(cherry picked from commit d3191eb939e4b3810878755273654ca91b35107e)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/79/878379/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - | The Octavia API returned an unhelpful message when a constraint failed while creating an object in the DB. The error now contains the name and the value of the parameter that breaks the constraints.

commit_message:
Fix unclear error messages in the API

Some API calls may have returned useless error messages such as

{"faultcode": "Client", "faultstring": " is not a valid option for ",
 "debuginfo": null}

when a DB constraint failed.

This commit improves the error message by reading the name of the
foreign key that failed from the exception.

The value of the parameters should have already been validated by WSME,
this exception is only thrown when there is an issue with the database
(corrupted DB, empty table or missing fields in a table).

Story 2009957
Task 44919

Change-Id: Idd6480bc0a7de7c42b34601172c2dae50077aa48
(cherry picked from commit 57e006eac321b210c98917019572b3576aefd97e)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/78/878378/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - | The Octavia API returned an unhelpful message when a constraint failed while creating an object in the DB. The error now contains the name and the value of the parameter that breaks the constraints.

commit_message:
Fix prometheus-proxy systemd service

This patch changes the inter-dependency between the prometheus-proxy
systemd service unit and the amphora-agent service. This will stop
systemd from shutting down the prometheus proxy should the amphora
agent be stopped.

Change-Id: I30c6c5809cc8568159feca193f38f62ca09874fd
(cherry picked from commit 7afe2fb24395665a45c66ee933e31b1b99b5c869)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/67/878367/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Wants=amphora-agent.service

commit_message:
Fix template issue with user_data_config_drive

Fix a python3 error that prevented to use the user_data_config_drive
option when building amphorae.

user_data_config_drive has been broken since we switched to python3,
a mix of str and bytes variables were provided to the jinja2 templates.
This commit ensures that the type of all the certificates provided to
jinja2 are strings.

Story: 2005553
Task: 30705

Change-Id: I53ed0425f00cfbbc964f5083b4f2942cf5bf565e
(cherry picked from commit 64d8d991f16dd818a981daa34ce418265a907b28)

commit_message:
Add functionality to configure virtual service IPs
(cherry picked from commit 4000b6ea72e9ca2350a24af87a22afdef08556af)

Closes-Bug: #1804057
func-test-pr: https://github.com/openstack-charmers/zaza-openstack-tests/pull/1021
Change-Id: I29f2eeca508048fdf8464193368cce5720559b9e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-designate-bind refs/changes/00/877100/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import sys from ipaddress import IPv4Address, IPv6Address # Modules imported from other interfaces/layers need to be mocked sys.modules[ 'relations.hacluster.interface_hacluster.common' ] = mock.MagicMock()class TestServiceIPFunctions(Helper): """Collection of tests for functions doing 'service_ip' configuration.""" def test_parse_service_ip_config(self): """Test function parsing 'service_ips' config option.""" service_ips = "10.0.0.1, 10.0.0.2, 2001:db8::2:1" with mock.patch.object(designate_bind.hookenv, 'config') as config: config.return_value = service_ips parsed_ips = designate_bind.parse_service_ip_config() expected_output = [ IPv4Address("10.0.0.1"), IPv4Address("10.0.0.2"), IPv6Address("2001:db8::2:1") ] self.assertEqual(expected_output, parsed_ips) def test_remove_service_ips(self): """Test removing already configured Service IPs.""" ip_to_remove = IPv4Address("10.0.0.1") ip_to_retain = IPv4Address("10.0.0.2") configured_resources = '["{0}{1}", "{0}{2}"]'.format( designate_bind.SERVICE_IP_PREFIX, ip_to_remove, ip_to_retain ) ha_cluster = mock.MagicMock() ha_cluster.get_local.return_value = configured_resources with mock.patch.object(designate_bind.reactive, 'endpoint_from_flag', return_value=ha_cluster): designate_bind.remove_service_ips(exclude=[ip_to_retain]) ha_cluster.delete_resource.assert_called_once_with("{}{}".format( designate_bind.SERVICE_IP_PREFIX, ip_to_remove )) ha_cluster.remove_colocation.assert_called_once_with( designate_bind.COLOCATION_NAME ) ha_cluster.bind_resources.assert_called_once_with() def test_remove_service_ips_no_hacluster(self): """Test that warning is logged if there's no hacluster.""" with mock.patch.object(designate_bind.reactive, 'endpoint_from_flag', return_value=None): designate_bind.remove_service_ips() expected_message = ('No relation with "ha-cluster" charm. Nothing to ' 'clear.') expected_level = designate_bind.hookenv.WARNING designate_bind.hookenv.log.assert_called_with(expected_message, expected_level) def test_add_service_ips(self): """Test configuring Service IP via hacluster resources.""" ha_cluster_mock = mock.MagicMock() crm_mock = mock.MagicMock() crm_patch = mock.patch.object(designate_bind, 'CRM', return_value=crm_mock) crm_patch.start() add_ips = [IPv4Address("10.0.0.1"), IPv6Address("2001:db8::2:1")] expected_primitive_calls = [] all_ip_resources = [] for ip_ in add_ips: resource = "{}{}".format(designate_bind.SERVICE_IP_PREFIX, ip_) ip_type = "IPaddr2" if isinstance(ip_, IPv4Address) else "IPv6addr" expected_primitive_calls.append(mock.call( resource, "ocf:heartbeat:{}".format(ip_type), params="ip={}".format(ip_), op='monitor interval="10s"' )) all_ip_resources.append(resource) with mock.patch.object(designate_bind.reactive, 'endpoint_from_flag', return_value=ha_cluster_mock): designate_bind.add_service_ips(add_ips) crm_mock.primitive.assert_has_calls(expected_primitive_calls) crm_mock.colocation.assert_called_once_with( designate_bind.COLOCATION_NAME, -10, *all_ip_resources ) ha_cluster_mock.manage_resources.assert_called_once_with(crm_mock) crm_patch.stop() def test_add_service_ips_no_config(self): """Test that function passes when there are no IPs to configure.""" ha_cluster_mock = mock.MagicMock() with mock.patch.object(designate_bind.reactive, 'endpoint_from_flag', return_value=ha_cluster_mock): designate_bind.add_service_ips([]) ha_cluster_mock.manage_resources.assert_not_called() # Assert that we also clear flag that signals that service_ips config # option is configured and charm is waiting for hacluster relation. designate_bind.reactive.clear_flag.assert_called_with( designate_bind.AWAITING_HACLUSTER_FLAG ) def test_add_service_ips_no_hacluster(self): """Test that function sets correct flag if it's missing hacluster.""" with mock.patch.object(designate_bind.reactive, 'endpoint_from_flag', return_value=None): designate_bind.add_service_ips([IPv4Address("10.0.0.1")]) designate_bind.reactive.set_flag.assert_called_with( designate_bind.AWAITING_HACLUSTER_FLAG ) def test_asses_status_passes(self): """Test scenario where _assess_status passes without blocking charm.""" self.patch_object(designate_bind.openstack_charm.OpenStackCharm, '_assess_status') self.patch_object(designate_bind, 'parse_service_ip_config') designate_bind.reactive.is_flag_set.return_value = False charm_ = designate_bind.DesignateBindCharm() charm_._assess_status() designate_bind.parse_service_ip_config.assert_called_once_with() designate_bind.hookenv.status_set.assert_not_called() def test_assess_status_bad_ip_config(self): """Test that unit is blocked if 'service_ips' config has bad format.""" self.patch_object(designate_bind.openstack_charm.OpenStackCharm, '_assess_status') self.patch_object(designate_bind, 'parse_service_ip_config') designate_bind.parse_service_ip_config.side_effect = ValueError charm_ = designate_bind.DesignateBindCharm() charm_._assess_status() expected_state = designate_bind.hookenv.WORKLOAD_STATES.BLOCKED expected_message = ('Config option "service_ips" does not have an ' 'expected format.') designate_bind.hookenv.status_set.assert_called_once_with( expected_state, expected_message ) def test_assess_status_blocks_on_awaiting_hacluster(self): """Test that unit is blocked if it's awaiting hacluster relation. This occurs when 'service_ips' config option is set but relation with hacluster charm is missing. """ self.patch_object(designate_bind.openstack_charm.OpenStackCharm, '_assess_status') self.patch_object(designate_bind, 'parse_service_ip_config') designate_bind.reactive.is_flag_set.return_value = True charm_ = designate_bind.DesignateBindCharm() charm_._assess_status() expected_state = designate_bind.hookenv.WORKLOAD_STATES.BLOCKED expected_message = ('Failed to configure "service_ips", hacluster ' 'relation is missing.') designate_bind.hookenv.status_set.assert_called_once_with( expected_state, expected_message )

commit_message:
[Wallaby Only] Switch mixed-os job to OVN raft

Noticed while investigating the related bug, the
job should validate default raft method.

Also enable Controller Nodes to act as gateway.

Related-Bug: #2012240
Change-Id: I16ff70102e8ec46b6dd1f7362e44f691153bbfb0

commit_message:
Additional check to replace missing seeded file

The additional check is based on cluster being bootstrapped and the last
backup being a SST.

The change includes new function for checking the last backup was SST
and unittests to verify said function as well as the main
charm_check_func where the check is used and seeded file is replaced.

Closes-Bug: #2000107
Change-Id: I8e516059da5299cc0e0ce8ef0802d3a46abb1a54
(cherry picked from commit a86390aeabca27167e26f38afb202e7daf39b185)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-percona-cluster refs/changes/78/874978/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: BACKUP_INFO = "{data_dir}/xtrabackup_info"def last_backup_sst(): """ Check if the last backup was an SST The percona xtrabackup_info file (BACKUP_INFO) contains information about the last backup/sync to this node, including the type of backup, either incremental (IST) or full (SST). We return True if we can successfully determine the last backup was SST from the BACKUP_INFO file contents, otherwise we assume the last backup was an incremental and return False. @returns boolean """ result = False try: with open(BACKUP_INFO.format(data_dir=resolve_data_dir()), 'r') as f: lines = f.readlines() for line in lines: if re.match('^incremental = N($|\n)', line): result = True except FileNotFoundError: log("""Backup info file not found: %s, assuming last backup was incremental""" % BACKUP_INFO.format(data_dir=resolve_data_dir()), level=DEBUG) except Exception: log("""Unable to read backup info file: %s, assuming last backup was incremental""" % BACKUP_INFO.format(data_dir=resolve_data_dir()), level=DEBUG) return result # Ensure seeded file is replaced if told or after any SST event post # bootstrap. resolves bug #2000107 if (not seeded() and (ensure_seeded or (is_bootstrapped() and last_backup_sst()))):

commit_message:
Fix deprecated rule logic if the rule was deleted in policy directory.

The bug scenario:
- define deprecated rule in policy folder
- start a service
- enforce policies
- remove the rule in policy folder
- enforce policies

New default is applied to the rule,
but new and old defaults should be applied
(OR logic)
The patch fixes it.

Closes-Bug: 1977549
Change-Id: If11fe2da1163d6d3f16d133aeb207a055cf30de4

commit_message:
Switch Senlin to Alembic database migrations

sqlalchemy-migrate is no longer supported and we need to switch
to alembic for database migrations.

Change-Id: I2e51b4027f7af63944b5504ddcf50e9e48818259

commit_message:
Update url of "Unity Replication White Paper"

The website "www.emc.com" has been discontinued.

Replace the outdated link
"https://www.emc.com/collateral/white-papers/h15088-dell-emc-unity-replication-technologies.pdf"
with the link
"https://dl.dell.com/content/docu69886_dell-emc-unity-replication-technologies-a-detailed-review.pdf".

Change-Id: I3ab2cc28bef7524cec4f161c9d5417597df56b89
(cherry picked from commit 9714ae828e126f33a804b4cb6890e68ecde760b6)

added_lines: <<<<<<< HEAD (667c6d Merge "Correct group:reset_group_snapshot_status policy" int)======= https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v2/?expanded=force-detach-volume-detail#force-detach-volume Consistent group support ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ For a group to support consistent group snapshot, the group specs in the corresponding group type should have the following entry: .. code-block:: ini {'consistent_group_snapshot_enabled': <is> True} Similarly, for a volume to be in a group that supports consistent group snapshots, the volume type extra specs would also have the following entry: .. code-block:: ini {'consistent_group_snapshot_enabled': <is> True} Refer to :doc:`/admin/blockstorage-groups` for command lines detail. Volume replications ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ To enable volume replications, follow below steps: 1. On Unisphere, configure remote system and interfaces for replications. The way could be different depending on the type of replications - sync or async. Refer to `Unity Replication White Paper <https://dl.dell.com/content/docu69886_dell-emc-unity-replication-technologies-a-detailed-review.pdf>`_ for more detail. 2. Add `replication_device` to storage backend settings in `cinder.conf`, then restart Cinder Volume service. Example of `cinder.conf` for volume replications: .. code-block:: ini [unity-primary] san_ip = xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx ... replication_device = backend_id:unity-secondary,san_ip:yyy.yyy.yyy.yyy,san_password:****,max_time_out_of_sync:60 - Only one `replication_device` can be configured for each primary backend. - Keys `backend_id`, `san_ip`, `san_password`, and `max_time_out_of_sync` are supported in `replication_device`, while `backend_id` and `san_ip` are required. - `san_password` uses the same one as primary backend's if it is omitted. - `max_time_out_of_sync` is the max time in minutes replications are out of sync. It must be equal or greater than `0`. `0` means sync replications of volumes will be created. Note that remote systems for sync replications need to be created on Unity first. `60` will be used if it is omitted. #. Create a volume type with property `replication_enabled='<is> True'`. .. code-block:: console $ openstack volume type create --property replication_enabled='<is> True' type-replication #. Any volumes with volume type of step #3 will failover to secondary backend after `failover_host` is executed. .. code-block:: console $ cinder failover-host --backend_id unity-secondary stein@unity-primary #. Later, they could be failed back. .. code-block:: console $ cinder failover-host --backend_id default stein@unity-primary .. note:: The volume can be deleted even when it is participating in a replication. The replication session will be deleted from Unity before the LUN is deleted. >>>>>>> CHANGE (75423a Update url of "Unity Replication White Paper")

subject: Add detailed option to show a missing field for hypervisor
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2021-10-17 16:18:09.000000000', 'files': ['openstackclient/compute/v2/hypervisor.py', 'openstackclient/tests/unit/compute/v2/test_hypervisor.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient/commit/a3ef5ad31dc7b391822710bb784197328234ad31', 'message': 'Add detailed option to show a missing field for hypervisor

Currently, the 'Hypervisor Type' and 'host IP' fields of the result
are displayed as blank values regardless of the nova api version.

Depending on the nova api version, the api that is basically
called is as follows
< 2.53 : /os-hypervisors/{hypervisors_hostname_pattern}/search
> 2.53 : /os-hypervisors/detail?hypervisor_hostname_pattern=$PATTERN

Neither api returns the contents of the 'Hypervisor Type' and
'Host IP' fields of the result.

When the api version is 2.53 or higher,
adding the detailed option to the search function calls the
"/os-hypervisors/detail?hypervisor_hostname_pattern=$PATTERN" api.

In this api, values to be put in The 'Hypervisor Type' and
'Host IP' fields of the result.

story: 2009289
task: 43591
Change-Id: I1981383d0993b1b997e264123e7ff9c5fc46a507
'}]
commit_message:
Add detailed option to show a missing field for hypervisor

Currently, the 'Hypervisor Type' and 'host IP' fields of the result
are displayed as blank values regardless of the nova api version.

Depending on the nova api version, the api that is basically
called is as follows
< 2.53 : /os-hypervisors/{hypervisors_hostname_pattern}/search
> 2.53 : /os-hypervisors/detail?hypervisor_hostname_pattern=$PATTERN

Neither api returns the contents of the 'Hypervisor Type' and
'Host IP' fields of the result.

When the api version is 2.53 or higher,
adding the detailed option to the search function calls the
"/os-hypervisors/detail?hypervisor_hostname_pattern=$PATTERN" api.

In this api, values to be put in The 'Hypervisor Type' and
'Host IP' fields of the result.

story: 2009289
task: 43591
Change-Id: I1981383d0993b1b997e264123e7ff9c5fc46a507

added_lines: self.app.client_manager.compute.api_version = \ api_versions.APIVersion('2.52') def test_hypervisor_list_matching_option_found_post_v253(self): self.app.client_manager.compute.api_version = \ api_versions.APIVersion('2.53') arglist = [ '--matching', self.hypervisors[0].hypervisor_hostname, ] verifylist = [ ('matching', self.hypervisors[0].hypervisor_hostname), ] parsed_args = self.check_parser(self.cmd, arglist, verifylist) # Fake the return value of search() self.hypervisors_mock.search.return_value = [self.hypervisors[0]] self.data = ( ( self.hypervisors[0].id, self.hypervisors[0].hypervisor_hostname, self.hypervisors[1].hypervisor_type, self.hypervisors[1].host_ip, self.hypervisors[1].state, ), ) # In base command class Lister in cliff, abstract method take_action() # returns a tuple containing the column names and an iterable # containing the data to be listed. columns, data = self.cmd.take_action(parsed_args) self.hypervisors_mock.search.assert_called_with( self.hypervisors[0].hypervisor_hostname, detailed=True ) self.assertEqual(self.columns, columns) self.assertEqual(self.data, tuple(data))

commit_message:
Improve the Fluentd configuration of the Elasticsearch output plugin

We had the problem that Fluentd built up a log buffer that it could no
longer reduce. This has caused a very high load on the systems.

This adjustment to the configuration of the output plugin for Elasticsearch
has now prevented the problem from occurring for weeks.

Change-Id: Idc583c09cf653c69f12d594775e948436db429d5

commit_message:
Add support for configuring Elasticsearch replication

Closes-Bug: #1939105
Change-Id: Icd04f7948ad6920176a70499ca6855a2e0b10837
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/54/805954/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Replication ----------- By default ES indices have replication factor equal to 1. It means that ES cluster will try to make one copy of every index's primary shard. Every copy (replica) must reside on a different cluster node than primary shard or other copies of the same shard. This of course is not be possible in a single-node deployments, where all of the newly created indices immediately go into a yellow health status which means warning. It's possible to modify replicas number in order to get rid of the yellow health state or to be extra safe with higher number of index copies in case of 3+ node clusters. To create an index template that changes replica count for future indices: .. code-block:: console curl -s -X PUT -H "Content-Type: application/json" {{ es_cluster_ip }}:9200/_template/flog_template -d '{"index_patterns":["flog-*"],"settings":{"number_of_shards":1,"number_of_replicas":0}}' In order to modify all the already existing indices, run: .. code-block:: console curl -s -X PUT -H "Content-Type: application/json" “{{ es_cluster_ip }}:9200/flog-*/_settings/” -d '{"index":{"number_of_replicas":0}}' with desired value for the ``number_of_replicas``.

commit_message:
Avoid generating haproxy services configs on nodes without appropriate services

The change excludes generating haproxy services.d config files
for services which hosted on non control hostgroup
in case of the nodes have their own balancer.
We can separate traffic from one input point (control group ) to several points.
Control plane can be free from non core services like Elastic etc.

Change-Id: Iaddaad49f65ab6176e1fccbff0ad1f8875bad603

commit_message:
Adds ability to group stacktraces into single fluentd message

Adds configurations for the fluent-plugin-detect-exceptions
fluentd plugin. This allows fluentd to recognize stacktraces
in logs and group them in a single message.

Closes-Bug: #1969391
Signed-off-by: Juan Pablo Suazo <jsuazo@whitestack.com>
Change-Id: Ieba4109e61c38664566483b74b46dd4c8beb933b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/64/838564/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- features: - | [`bug 1969391 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/kolla-ansible/+bug/1969391>`_] Adds matching block with the detect_exceptions plugin in order to group stacktrace logs in a single message. In order to avoid recursive matching and deadlock errors, the rewrite_tag plugin is used. Firstly it adds the 'pre_detect_except.post_rewrite.' tag to all outgoing messages. The first tag is used to match all messages in order to check if a stacktrace is present. The tag is then removed after the check. If this was not the case, and the tag remained the same, the same messages would match again and again, resulting in an error. In a similar manner, the rewrite_tag plugin matches all messages with tags that dont begin with either 'pre_detect_except.' or 'post_rewrite.'. Without the first restriction, all messages would match recuresively as the plugin would add this tag to a message and immediately match again. The second restriction makes sure that messages are not matched again by the rewrite_tag plugin once the detect_exceptions plugin removes the first half of the added tag.

commit_message:
Deploy mariaDB Galera arbitrator

In case of failure (network breakdown, hardware failure),
the quorum can be altered and thus the mariaDB cluster may
become non-operationnal until the quorum is reached again.
This feature will help to deploy a new group of hosts that
will run the Galera arbitrator and help out to guarantee the
quorum and keep the mariaDB cluster running.
More info about Galera arbitrator here:
https://galeracluster.com/library/documentation/arbitrator.html

Change-Id: I9618d1f14de2c1498724298342d52377a408cce3
Implements: blueprint maria-arbitrator-quorum
Co-Authored-By: Patricio Tula <patricio.tula-ext@socgen.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/96/728796/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: Copying mariadb_arbitrator.cnf for arbitrator vars: service_name: "mariadb_arbitrator" service: "{{ mariadb_services[service_name] }}" merge_configs: sources: - "{{ role_path }}/templates/mariadb_arbitrator.cnf.j2" dest: "{{ node_config_directory }}/{{ service_name }}/mariadb_arbitrator.cnf" owner: "{{ config_owner_user }}" group: "{{ config_owner_group }}" mode: "0660" register: arbitrator_config become: true when: - inventory_hostname in groups[service.group] - service.enabled | bool - name: Copying over config.json files for arbitrator vars: service_name: "mariadb_arbitrator" service: "{{ mariadb_services[service_name] }}" template: src: "{{ service_name }}.json.j2" dest: "{{ node_config_directory }}/{{ service_name }}/config.json" mode: "0660" register: arbitrator_config_json become: true when: - inventory_hostname in groups[service.group] - service.enabled | bool notify: Restart arbitrator container

When the containers of groups['outward-rabbitmq'] and groups['rabbitmq']

"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2021-08-12 19:20:42.000000000', 'files': ['ansible/roles/rabbitmq/tasks/precheck.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/commit/75bfc68932d306f1f36e6fa4ba2c271e4996ccc1', 'message': "Detect outward-rabbitmq and rabbitmq group overlaps

"}]
commit_message:
Detect outward-rabbitmq and rabbitmq group overlaps

When the containers of groups['outward-rabbitmq'] and groups['rabbitmq']
are on the same physical machine, subsequent start of outward_rabbitmq of
groups['outward-rabbitmq'] will start to report an error. So add precheck
task to avoid this situation

Change-Id: I20056f511e95d217e926a59b8bc974d7cedeae73
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/47/801747/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: Check if groups['outward-rabbitmq'] and groups['rabbitmq'] are duplicate nodes fail: msg: groups['outward-rabbitmq'] and groups['rabbitmq'] do not allow duplicate nodes with_items: "{{ groups['outward-rabbitmq'] }}" when: - item in groups['rabbitmq'] - enable_outward_rabbitmq | bool run_once: true

commit_message:
Support UnionTech OS server enterprise when run 'prechecks' step.

UnionTech is a well-known operating system manufacturer in China, which is a debian-based release.
We hope that the UnionTech OS server enterprise can pass the 'prechecks' step. Now the UnionTech
OS has passed the 'prechecks' step and can be successfully deployed.

Change-Id: I46e5dbb96bda07ccbc8319168eac16f0f8f27852
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/76/795776/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: "UnionTech OS Server 20 Enterprise": - "20"

subject: unify the wsgi logfile name
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-05-22 04:42:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/commit/3dbac13dfa62ffcf1f29682ed7f02d91465a2420', 'message': 'unify the wsgi logfile name

Currently, wsgi logfile name is different everywhere

commit_message:
unify the wsgi logfile name

Currently, wsgi logfile name is somewhere different
in different components. After unifying logfile name,
fluentd log processor can benefit from it by using
wildcard regex expression as well as our sanity.

Change-Id: I7e7792d7cb264faba2de18209a4f9c70eaa15f8d
Signed-off-by: yaoning <yaoning@unitedstack.com>

deleted_lines: rewriterule1 programname ^(cinder-api-access|cloudkitty-api-access|gnocchi-api-access|horizon-access|keystone-apache-admin-access|keystone-apache-public-access|monasca-api-access|monasca-log-api-access|placement-api-access|panko-api-access)$ apache_access rewriterule2 programname ^(aodh_wsgi_access|barbican-api|zun_api_wsgi_access|vitrage_wsgi_access)$ wsgi_access

commit_message:
Remove kolla-cli from vagrant

The kolla-cli is deprecation [1], it should be clean up from
kolla-ansible

[1]: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/749045/

Change-Id: I27bbf91ff633349e1cc7da22174b63f52ab81de5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/10/755010/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # get kolla and kolla-ansibe repos path relative to current directory
deleted_lines: # get kolla, kolla-ansibe and kolla-cli repos path relative to current directorykolla_cli_repo_path = File.expand_path(File.join(vagrant_dir, '..', '..', '..', '..', 'kolla-cli')) kolla_cli_path = "#{user_home}/kolla-cli"

commit_message:
Support for custom API paste files

Implements mechanism of deploying custom API paste files overriding
default ones.
API paste files configures API requests pipelining and provide only way
how to implement auditing in OpenStack deployments.
Custom paste files are copied from following path:
{{ node_custom_config }}/{{ project_name }}/{{ project_name }}-api-paste.ini;
in case of override for neutron-server default api-paste.ini the path may be:
/etc/kolla/config/neutron/neutron-api-paste.ini
(in case the {{ node_custom_config }} points to /etc/kolla/config ).

Change-Id: I93e333667add275f353b213043de1c713f049167
Blueprint: custom-paste
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/54/695054/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: Check if custom api-paste is present local_action: stat path="{{ item }}" run_once: True register: heat_api_paste with_first_found: - files: - "api-paste.ini" paths: - "{{ node_custom_config }}/heat/" skip: true - name: Set heat api-paste file set_fact: heat_api_paste_file: "{{ heat_api_paste.results.0.stat.path | basename }}" heat_api_paste_file_path: "{{ heat_api_paste.results.0.stat.path }}" when: - heat_api_paste.results - name: Copying over existing api-paste file become: true template: src: "{{ heat_api_paste_file_path }}" dest: "{{ node_config_directory }}/heat-api/{{ heat_api_paste_file }}" mode: "0660" register: heat_api-paste_overwriting when: - heat_api_paste_file is defined - inventory_hostname in groups['heat-api'] with_dict: "{{ heat_services['heat-api'] }}" notify: - Restart heat-api container

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-09-02 16:14:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/commit/f77e3a71f2b2084f75c8567b57e583ad9cdc180d', 'message': 'Don't set hostname in monasca-agent-collector's config

`ansible_hostname` returns the unqualified hostname, which is then used
by the Monasca Agent (specifically the Libvirt plugin) to retrieve the
list of instances running on this hypervisor. However in deployments
where fully qualified hostnames are used as hypervisor names, this will
result in the list of instances being empty and the Agent complaining
about "ghost instances".

The Agent is capable of finding out the hostname of the host it's
running on automatically (using `hostname -f`) but the value specified
in the config file takes precedence. Hence this commit removes the
config parameter entirely.

extract the unqualified part of the "hostname" parameter and use it as
fallback if the specified FQDN doesn't match exactly.

commit_message:
Don't set hostname in monasca-agent-collector's config

`ansible_hostname` returns the unqualified hostname, which is then used
by the Monasca Agent (specifically the Libvirt plugin) to retrieve the
list of instances running on this hypervisor. However in deployments
where fully qualified hostnames are used as hypervisor names, this will
result in the list of instances being empty and the Agent complaining
about "ghost instances".

The Agent is capable of finding out the hostname of the host it's
running on automatically (using `hostname -f`) but the value specified
in the config file takes precedence. Hence this commit removes the
config parameter entirely.

An alternative would be to use `ansible_fqdn` instead, as the Agent can
extract the unqualified part of the "hostname" parameter and use it as
fallback if the specified FQDN doesn't match exactly.

Change-Id: Ia817e1d096fcd46af33c9c57888e22c1021c14fb
Closes-Bug: 1894076
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/47/749547/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Configure proxy settings for bootstrap-servers

Behind proxy, there were several resources to be blocked to be
provisoned (apt / pip / dockerd...). Add new variables to configure
proxy called 'host_http_proxy', 'host_https_proxy' and
'host_no_proxy'.

User can use those variables for bootstrap-servers phase.

Change-Id: I39a63ef0627246279a5a74fe44a4bc855bbe77fc
Closes-Bug: #1829586
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/06/692006/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - not http_proxy | length > 0 - not https_proxy | length > 0 when: docker_custom_option | length > 0 or docker_configure_for_zun|bool or http_proxy | length > 0 or https_proxy | length > 0- name: Write docker proxy drop-in template: src: http-proxy.conf.j2 dest: /etc/systemd/system/docker.service.d/http-proxy.conf when: http_proxy | length > 0 or https_proxy | length > 0

Use api-paste.ini from cyborg rather kolla-ansible

Kolla-ansible should not maintance the api-paste.ini, and better way is
get it from cyborg projects. Also keep consistences with other roles.

commit_message:
multipath.conf should be configureable

check if there is a multipath.conf in custom_config and use this file
directly instead of "generating" one out of the kolla templated file.

Change-Id: I0a1ab8c7e0f3085261e29a07bd52f478dce8be26
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/11/726211/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: Check if multipath.conf exists in node_custom_config local_action: stat path={{ node_custom_config }}/multipath.conf register: stat_multipath_conf - name: Copying over multipath.conf (template) - ! stat_multipath_conf.stat.exists with_dict: "{{ multipathd_services }}" notify: - Restart multipathd container - name: Copying over multipath.conf (custom_config) template: src: "{{ node_custom_config }}/multipath.conf" dest: "{{ node_config_directory }}/{{ item.key }}/multipath.conf" mode: "0660" become: true when: - inventory_hostname in groups[item.value.group] - item.value.enabled | bool - stat_multipath_conf.stat.exists

commit_message:
Support Pacemaker

Currently, Keepalived is used for controlling VIP based upon
the healthy check result of HAproxy.

This PS lets kolla-ansible to support Pacemaker as HA manager. It
simply replace Keepalived and Keepalived's current function in
kolla-ansible. User can choose to use Pacemaker or Keepalived
by setting 'enabled_pacemaker' option.

Change-Id: Ia04d47d1b2be4222aa54c0da7e2199db8b21c5b6
Implements: blueprint use-pacemaker-in-kolla

commit_message:
Provide sensible default cell group names

By providing sensible default group names for cells, the user no longer
has to define the group names for each cell manually in group vars.

This also updates the CI test, which uses non-default group names.

Partially Implements: blueprint support-nova-cells
Change-Id: Iaca3462698e29d742876b677b05c3a5c115b8caf

commit_message:
Add 'clients' command for installing OSC clients

Support installing OSC clients compatible with the services that are
managed by the deployment. Clients can be installed in a virtualenv, but
are by default installed on the deploy node (where the admin-openrc.sh
file already is.)

Usage:

  kolla-ansible -i INVENTORY clients

Change-Id: I8d2f9b78668bac5e07269411914a18c298b88bc3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/76/671576/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: Install OpenStack clients on the deploy node hosts: localhost become: true tasks: - name: Generating requirements.txt template: src: "roles/common/templates/requirements.txt.j2" dest: "{{ node_config }}/requirements.txt" run_once: True - pip: requirements: "{{ node_config }}/requirements.txt" virtualenv: "{{ virtualenv is none | ternary(omit, virtualenv) }}" extra_args: "-c https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/requirements/plain/upper-constraints.txt?h=stable/{{ openstack_release }}" run_once: True

subject: Make ironic cross gating voting
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-07-15 16:00:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/4f7fda0c9a01f5d0132c41d1ca03fa9a80969ad1', 'message': 'Make ironic cross gating voting

The majority of ironic's CI is built upon devstack, and thus some changes
which may pass setting up a stock devstack, may still ultimately cripple
Ironic's CI. Mainly in terms of integration with other projects.

As such, it seems logical to make the CI job voting such that breaking
changes have visibility upfront.

Also re-names the job name to the more modern name as the
driver name the job mentions was explicitly removed some time
ago in favor of what is called driver composition.

This change came out of a discussion of Neutron changing the default to
OVN. Which while problematic for Ironic due to a lack of necessary DHCP
server capabilities, the topic of the neturon-legacy/neutron plugin came
up and Ironic, and at the time of this change Ironic uses the "neutron"
plugin. As such, abrupt removal of the plugin would be a fairly
catastropic change for Ironic, hence the need for cross-gating.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/741254/
Change-Id: I5d6a4fccf37521f0104091ecb8055a08f760fa05

commit_message:
Make ironic cross gating voting

The majority of ironic's CI is built upon devstack, and thus some changes
which may pass setting up a stock devstack, may still ultimately cripple
Ironic's CI. Mainly in terms of integration with other projects.

As such, it seems logical to make the CI job voting such that breaking
changes have visibility upfront.

Also re-names the job name to the more modern name as the
driver name the job mentions was explicitly removed some time
ago in favor of what is called driver composition.

This change came out of a discussion of Neutron changing the default to
OVN. Which while problematic for Ironic due to a lack of necessary DHCP
server capabilities, the topic of the neturon-legacy/neutron plugin came
up and Ironic, and at the time of this change Ironic uses the "neutron"
plugin. As such, abrupt removal of the plugin would be a fairly
catastropic change for Ironic, hence the need for cross-gating.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/741254/
Change-Id: I5d6a4fccf37521f0104091ecb8055a08f760fa05

commit_message:
fix the name of uwsgi from uwsgi to uWSGI.
it produces a error message that ls can not access uwsgi, No such file or directory when using comman ls uwsgi. Because package name starts with uWSGI not uwsgi.

Change-Id: Ia6d1617f0d3538d8728d4da689368cf7c96f02fc

added_lines: uwsgi=$(ls uWSGI*) cd ./apache2

commit_message:
swift: Remove s3api from proxy pipeline

...in case Swift ever starts recommending s3api by default.
Otherwise, we'll have it placed twice.

commit_message:
Make cirros image download automatically on multiarch

This makes devstack download the right cirros image automatically when
running on multiarch nodes such as aarch64, x86_64 and ppc64le.

Change-Id: I056a68b01f84b2cb40f8af8e0962640c86e139d6

floating IP range set up by neutron.

commit_message:
zuul: Added reference tenant configuration

For users who want to consume DevStack in their own Zuul tenants,
they can use this sample tenant configuration which includes how to
loads jobs and all projects.

Change-Id: Ie7ad88f296976e45c4b115a3de4e70aead071733
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/54/713454/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: The DevStack repository includes a set of Zuul CI jobs which can be used by any project inside OpenStack but also by third parties that need to integrate their systems and test them against OpenStack using Zuul. The following is an example of a Zuul tenant with all the needed ``required-projects`` which consumes DevStack. .. code-block:: yaml - tenant: name: devstack max-nodes-per-job: 10 report-build-page: true source: gerrit: untrusted-projects: - zuul/zuul-jobs # Include all the necessary jobs - include: [job, nodeset] projects: - openstack/devstack - openstack/tempest # Include all the required-projects - include: [] projects: - openstack/cinder - openstack/glance - openstack/keystone - openstack/neutron - openstack/nova - openstack/oslo.cache - openstack/oslo.concurrency - openstack/oslo.config - openstack/oslo.context - openstack/oslo.db - openstack/oslo.i18n - openstack/oslo.log - openstack/oslo.messaging - openstack/oslo.middleware - openstack/oslo.policy - openstack/oslo.privsep - openstack/oslo.reports - openstack/oslo.rootwrap - openstack/oslo.serialization - openstack/oslo.service - openstack/oslo.utils - openstack/oslo.versionedobjects - openstack/oslo.vmware - openstack/placement - openstack/requirements - openstack/swift Jobs ----

commit_message:
Fix api layer become slow when shutdown one control node

* add memcache_socket_timeout configuration variables
  and set the default value 0.25[0]
* add memcache_dead_retry configuration variables
  and set the default value to 900s[1]

* [0] https://review.opendev.org/519353
* [1] https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.cache/latest/configuration/#cache.memcache_dead_retry
Closes-Bug: #1980739

Change-Id: I47db333a1f0d735703e6559e2130315189e3d56e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/87/849487/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: memcache_dead_retry = 3600 memcache_socket_timeout = 0.25

subject: Always run the rabbitmq heartbeat inside a standard pthread.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-05-24 14:50:44.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs/commit/75cab832e352ff1cc3ebb8b4c10cf325528ae192', 'message': "[WIP] allow customers to use python standard threads on rabbitmq driver

Propose changes to introduce 2 executions mode for the oslo.messaging
rabbitmq driver:
- mode where eventlet is in use during execution
- mode where python standards thread is in use during execution

The default mode is to use eventlet to don't break existing usages.

Users can switch mode at start by using some additional configuration:
```
[oslo_messaging_rabbit]
eventlet_mode=off
```

Change-Id: Ia6d873c3fc5dcc6b1c181b983b9d0d2787348163
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2019-05-29 11:49:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs/commit/c17e1fe4d7e8352a732b927754167f9171cda82c', 'message': "[WIP] Run heartbeat in a standard pthread by default.

Propose changes to introduce 2 executions mode for the oslo.messaging
rabbitmq driver:
- synchronous execution model based on pthreads [default]
- asynchronous execution model that user can choose to use if needed.

The default mode is to use the python stdlib threading module to run
heartbeat. In mostly use case the user do not take care about the async
mode for the AMQP heartbeat.

The proposed changes will fix related issues who run heartbeat under
mod_wsgi in a monkey patched environment.

If it's really needed users can choose to switch to an async exuction
model by using:
```
[oslo_messaging_rabbit]
async_heartbeat_mode=on
```

In this case the driver will have to check that it's possible to run
async heartbeat (not under mod_wsgi, etc...) and will have to inform
user if the async mode should be forced to off by sending related logs.

Change-Id: Ia6d873c3fc5dcc6b1c181b983b9d0d2787348163

commit_message:
Always run the rabbitmq heartbeat inside a standard pthread.

Propose changes to always run the rabbitmq health check heartbeat in a
standard python thread.

With the described specs we want to isolate the heartbeat execution model
from the parent process inherited execution model.

We want to force to use the python stdlib threading module to run
heartbeat.

The proposed changes will fix related issues who run heartbeat under
mod_wsgi in a monkey patched environment.

Change-Id: Ia6d873c3fc5dcc6b1c181b983b9d0d2787348163
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs refs/changes/14/661314/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ============================================================================== Allow customer to choose to use std threads or greenthreads in rabbitmq driver ============================================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo.messaging/+spec/rabbitmq-driver-threads oslo.messaging RabbitMq driver use greenthreads from eventlet. In some use case it can be useful to also can use python standard threads. This allow customers design that they need exactly in their context. This specification proposes changes to adapt the rabbitmq driver to provide mechanismes needed to lets customers choice between eventlet greenthreads or python standard threads. Problem description =================== The rabbitmq driver is commonly used to healt check the AMQP connections with rabbitmq to ensure connections by using the driver heartbeat mechanism. The AMQP heartbeat can be used in mod_wsgi. the threading library is monkey_patched by eventlet, and it's not compatible with mod_wsgi. Indeed, mod_wsgi stops the execution of its embedded interpreter, the AMQP heartbeat thread can't be resumed until there's a message to be processed in the mod_wsgi queue, which would resume the python interpreter and make eventlet resume the thread. Allow customers to use standard threads and disabling eventlet will fix this kind of issues. Proposed change =============== The spec proposes to introduce a new configuration option who lets customers choose the threading mode to use. By default we'll keep the eventlet mode with the monkey patched threading module, and user by using configuration will can choose to turn off the eventlet mode and to use the non monkey patched mode. The ``eventlet_mode`` config option will be introduced, with the default value defined to turned on (``on``). User can choose to set this value to ``off`` to turn off the eventlet mode and using python standard threads. This option will have a default value so doesn't need to update existing usages. Also the existing usages of this driver will continue to have the same behaviors if nobody changes the configuration explicitely so it's transparent for end users. Here is a example that describes the introduced option turned off:: [oslo_messaging_rabbit] eventlet_mode = off Alternatives ------------ Remove eventlet on the rabbitmq driver and prefer to use possible alternatives like using futurist. Impact on Existing usages ------------------------- No impact on the existing usages since the default behavior will continue to use eventlet by default (``eventlet_mode=on``). Security impact --------------- There's a slim chance that driver behavior could change if pre-existing environment variables are present that happen to match the new option name described here. Performance Impact ------------------ No significant performance impact is expected. Configuration Impact -------------------- A new option will be added that can impact users in some unidentified scenarios. Developer Impact ---------------- Developers will have an additional customization option available. Testing Impact -------------- Additional unit tests will be required to cover the added functionality. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: hberaud Other contributors: volunteers? Milestones ---------- ..TODO(hberaud): figure this out Work Items ---------- * Implement the described modes in rabbitmq driver. * Update documentation. * Update the sample configuration generator to include the variable names. * Update the documentation generator to include the variable names. Incubation ========== N/A Documentation Impact ==================== The documentation will need to be updated to indicate the option can be overridden with an environment variable and to describe how the described modes works. Dependencies ============ N/A References ========== * Eventlet Best Practices: `https://review.opendev.org/#/c/154642/`_ * Related discussion on the ML about mod_wsgi and monkey patch: `http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005305.html`_ .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

commit_message:
Skip returning unwanted internal data to user

Various RestFul APIs returns below internal unwanted data to the user:-

trust_id of a lease
resource_id of a reservation
aggregate_id of an instance reservation
trust_id of a host

This patch will not return above data if the microversion is 1.1.

APIImpact:
1)For microversion 1.1, trust_id of a lease, resource_id of a
reservation, aggregate_id of an instance reservation are not returned
in response while creating, updating and getting the lease.

2)For microversion 1.1, trust_id of a host is not returned in
response while creating, updating and getting the host.

Change-Id: Ie6205af3052c972cdb6fb8a9f00afa5c2c8d72a7
Closes-Bug: #1740091

added_lines: [testenv:linters] # Env vars and deps need to be defined in top level tox env setenv = ANSIBLE_LIBRARY = {toxinidir}/ansible/library ANSIBLE_ACTION_PLUGINS = {toxinidir}/ansible/action_plugins ANSIBLE_FILTER_PLUGINS = {toxinidir}/ansible/filter_plugins deps = -c{env:UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE:https://releases.openstack.org/constraints/upper/master} -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt -r{toxinidir}/doc/requirements.txt whitelist_externals = bash commands = ; {[testenv:pep8]commands} {[testenv:doc8]commands} ; {[testenv:bandit]commands} ; {[testenv:bashate]commands} ; {[testenv:yamllint]commands} [testenv:doc8] deps = {[testenv:linters]deps} commands = doc8 doc/source specs doc8 -e '.yaml' releasenotes/notes/

commit_message:
Glance Cinder backend

Implement proper support for the Glance's Cinder backend on demand
instead of enabling a broken support by default.

There were several bits missing from the original logic that kept
the Cinder backend kind of available but broken in multiple ways.
For details, please see the bug reports and the attached release
note.

Docs included as well.

Closes-Bug: #1928669
Closes-Bug: #1831002
Related-Bug: #1854194
Change-Id: Ia5198e4f2c12290546be7204e94d6bc72c7868a6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/99/714999/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: glance_backend_cinder: "yes"

commit_message:
Remove the deprecated enable_ironic_pxe_uefi

Change-Id: Ie687d9fc6e4c791dcf419e0620bdc743de795733
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/38/859838/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: - not enable_ironic_pxe_uefi | bool- name: Copying ironic_pxe_uefi.cfg default vars: service: "{{ ironic_services['ironic-tftp'] }}" template: src: "{{ item }}" dest: "{{ node_config_directory }}/ironic-tftp/default" mode: "0660" become: true with_first_found: - "{{ node_custom_config }}/ironic/ironic_pxe_uefi.default" - "{{ node_custom_config }}/ironic/{{ inventory_hostname }}/ironic_pxe_uefi.default" - "ironic_pxe_uefi.default.j2" when: - inventory_hostname in groups[service.group] - service.enabled | bool - enable_ironic_pxe_uefi | bool notify: - Restart ironic-tftp container - not enable_ironic_pxe_uefi | bool

subject: [CI] Change the Zun scenario to altcomp scenario
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-07-27 10:10:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/commit/f695103be40fe385a4753a193f2a04632de14743', 'message': '[CI] Change the Zun scenario to altcomp scenario

As discussed some time ago, we prefer to have the altcomp scenario
which covers other ways to deploy the compute. This would normally
include also Zun but now it is being removed due to the decline
in activity as well as it being broken on multiple fronts. [1] [2]

At the moment, the scenario runs multinode compute with Cinder
LVM-backed volumes. This is our only scenario to test non-Ceph
Cinder (which is best to validate if only Ceph is affected).
In the future, this may (and likely will) include the deployment
of additional services, like Blazar.

Glossary

altcomp = alternative compute

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/zun/+/851196
[2] https://bugs.launchpad.net/zun/+bug/1982924

Change-Id: I2651be1b5073b3395e47e8d0de1b540cb6d17457
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2022-08-12 16:29:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/commit/f204d1bb6433e2e7059598481bfdb6ec1a11d0cb', 'message': '[CI] Change the Zun scenario to altcomp scenario

At the moment, the scenario runs multinode compute with Cinder

commit_message:
[CI] Change the Zun scenario to altcomp scenario

As discussed some time ago, we prefer to have the alternative
compute (altcomp) scenario which covers other ways to deploy
the compute plane.
The scenario keeps Zun but the new name reinforces the fact
that this scenario is testing more than Zun.

At the moment, the scenario runs multinode compute with Cinder
LVM-backed volumes. This is our only scenario to test non-Ceph
Cinder (which is best to validate if only Ceph is affected).
In the future, this may (and likely will) include the deployment
of additional services, like Blazar, similarly to how Zun is
included currently.

Change-Id: I2651be1b5073b3395e47e8d0de1b540cb6d17457

commit_message:
Get OVS assignment right

As reported in the linked bug, the OVS role has issues with actual
placement. This patch gets it right. It avoids the use of static
inventory entirely and is backwards compatible. Only correct hosts
will now have the OVS logic applied.

Closes-Bug: #1971488
Change-Id: Ie92b6a27a656491601606b76e410e247f82b46b1

commit_message:
Add the NATS transport driver to oslo.messaging

nats-transport is the spec for a new transport driver for
oslo.messaging to use the NATS messaging system.

Change-Id: Ic6346947bbf650fb53581842c64fdec99090c242
Blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo.messaging/+spec/nats-transport
Co-Authored-By: Hervé Beraud <hberaud@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs refs/changes/84/692784/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: =====================================:wq NATS Driver for Messaging Transport ===================================== This specification proposes a new transport driver for oslo.messaging that uses NATS. NATS is a high-performance messaging system [1]_ [2]_ written in Go. NATS is designed as a central nervous system for the cloud control plane [3]_. While NATS Sreaming has message persistency like RabbitMQ, NATS itself doesn't but it's not a problem for oslo.messaging because every message has its own lifetime. NATS server supports clustering for high availability. Problem description =================== RabbitMQ is widely used in OpenStack deployments but it has problems: * Big footprint: RabbitMQ is only one using Erlang for a typical OpenStack deployment and it requires 40MB+ disk space and ~30 packages in Ubuntu. RDO stein contains 43 packages of Erlang. * HA performance: "Avoid multiple nodes (HA)" is one of the best practices from the point of view of performance [4]_. * HA stability: Japanese OpenStackers discussed RabbitMQ operation problems at OpenStack Ops Workshop #6 at Tokyo [5]_ and an attendee said that clustered RabbitMQ servers in his OpenStack deployment suddenly died without failover and he decided to stop using RabbitMQ clustering. Proposed change =============== Implements a new driver of oslo.messaging to use NATS as the RPC and notification message transport. It uses pynats2 [6]_, threading based python 3.6+ client for NATS. Impact on Existing APIs ----------------------- Nothing. Security impact --------------- Nothing. The NATS driver should have 2 security capabilities like other drivers: authentication and encryption. pynats2 python client library has both, so we can use them in the driver. Performance Impact ------------------ Nothing. Configuration Impact -------------------- To use the NATS driver, spefify the value for transport_url in section [Default]: transport_url = nats://[user:pass@]host[:port][,[userN:passN@]hostN:portN]/[virtual_host] For TLS connection, transport_url = nats+tls://[user:pass@]host[:port][,[userN:passN@]hostN:portN]/[virtual_host] The default value of port is 4222. You can specify multiple hosts with each user:pass. The NATS server doesn't support virtual host but pynats2 module has pseudo virtual host capability and the driver uses it. The driver has options in section [oslo_messaging_nats]: socket_timeout: Seconds to waiting recieved data from NATS server Type: float Default value: 2.0 ping_interval: Interval in seconds to send PING to NATS server Type: float Default value: 10.0 tls_verify: Verify the NATS server certificate Type: bool Default value: False tls_cacert: path to the CA certificate file for the NATS server verification Type: string tls_client_cert: path to the client certificate file for the NATS connection Type: string tls_client_key: path to the client key file for the NATS connection Type: string Developer Impact ---------------- Nothing. Testing Impact -------------- The NATS server will be used as the messaging backend for RPC and notifications in testing. No alternative backend such as RabbitMQ or Apache Kafka should be used. The NATS driver tests should be implemented and the driver must pass all tests. The driver must pass the following gate checks with deployed in a hybrid messaging configuration. * oslo.messaging-tox-py36-func-nats pynats2 python client library only supports Python 3.6+. It doesn't use asyncio, so we can make it available with Python 2.x. However, Python 2.x will be unsupported on Jan 1st, 2020, and the NATS driver won't be required backward compatibility because it's new one, so gates for Python 2.x won't be used or implemented for it. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: akirayoshiyama@gmail.com (Akira72 or yosshy on IRC) Other contributors: No one for now. Contributors are welcome. Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: V release Work Items ---------- * Deploy environment for latest software release and dependencies * Implement the NATS driver * Write documentation * Functional test integration * Implement devstack plugin * Upstream CI integration * Send announcement to openstack-discuss following release Incubation ========== None. Adoption -------- The NATS driver is expected to be adopted in many deployments which operators doesn't like to use RabbitMQ. Library ------- oslo.messaging Anticipated API Stabilization ----------------------------- None Documentation Impact ==================== The NATS driver documentation will be added to the libary. This documentation will follow the style of documentation provided by the other drivers and should include the following topics: * theory of operation (overview) of the NATS messaging backend * pre-requisites * driver options overview * the NATS server operations * devstack support * platforms and software Dependencies ============ The driver will require pynats2, threading based NATS python client. References ========== .. [1] https://nats.io/ .. [2] https://bravenewgeek.com/dissecting-message-queues/ .. [3] https://nats.io/blog/introducing-nats-streaming/#why-nats-streaming .. [4] https://www.cloudamqp.com/blog/2018-01-08-part2-rabbitmq-best-practice-for-high-performance.html#avoid-multiple-nodes-ha .. [5] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/JP-Ops-workshop-6-rabbit .. [6] https://github.com/yosshy/pynats2 .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

commit_message:
Test created encrypted volume type

Created encrypted volume type is not tested properly
to know if that is created successfully or usable or not.

This commit adds the created encrypted volume type in bootale
volume creation request which is used to boot instance from.

Related-Bug: #1926630
Related-Bug: #1938763
Change-Id: Id16f5b57e88a1efe52a51a83656d770d190695aa

commit_message:
Project Stopwatch

This is a proposal to change our release cycles, simplifying
our procedures.

Change-Id: I1875855e8accfbb7ff64af1781f0856c12760c11
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ideas refs/changes/29/718929/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Project Stopwatch: Changing the release cycle ============================================= Despite talking regularly about changing release cycles, we keep the same process, and our releases cycles stay about 6 months long. There are multiple issues we should look at: pressure on our contributors, large delays (around 6 months) if you miss the feature freeze, inflexible release models, lack of contributions/releases in stable branches for some projects. The pressure on our contributors comes from multiple aspects. On top of being shorthanded, we have many release cycle deadlines, including a very stressful feature freeze for which many developers can't wait the next release to have their feature included and must apply pressure to get their work merged in time. Having a longer release cycles wouldn't help our people as there would be even more pressure on our current deadlines (like library and feature freezes). However, after the feature freeze, more time could be spent for project maintenance and janitoring. Would shorter cycles solve those main issues? Not really. What we gain in agility (it would help to not wait for 6 months when missing a release deadline), would directly translate into the pressure on individuals. At first sight, the same amount of work would need to be done in less time. It is worth noting that increasing the amount of feature freezes would reduce the pressure at each feature freeze. My proposal to solve those issues is to remap and automate what's happening inside a cycle, increase the amount of feature freezes, and relax the requirements of what needs to happen in a cycle. Its advantages are: less pressure on individuals, increased stability, reduced load on maintainers, and decrease the importance of "coordinated" releasing. Its main inconvenient would be to have more "freeze" time, slowering the pace (though this could be considered an advantage), and reduce the attractiveness on occasional maintainers (this has to be balanced with the healthy improvements of a reduced pace for the rest of the community). The stopwatch (tick-tock) model for coordinated release -------------------------------------------------------- For the "coordinated" releases, we would take a "tick-tock" approach, where one month the features are introduced ('tick', on odd months), and on the next month ('tock'), we'll stabilise. It introduces: * a specific focus each month * more feature freezes (every odd month) * more time for bug fixing (every other month), helping on stability * a standard rhythm for the community * more opportunities to ramp up the community members It removes: * the complexity of the current schedule * the need for release candidates * a bit of the speed of the current developments Please note that new developments do not have to stop or be abandonned in the "stabilisation" month. They are just not merged until we are sure the rest of the code is stabilized. Long term contributors will have more time to focus on project janitorial work. I also hope this extra time of stabilization could be spent on growing the community, and more mentoring. However, a negative side-effect would be that some features contributions could take longer to merge, as the features only happen on "tick" months. This side-effect should be carefully examinated before a policy like this can be set in place. The rhythm proposed could be used to automate release proposals. To kickstart this, we could convert all the "cycle-with-rc", "cycle-with-intermediary", and "cycle-automatic" projects into a single release model, behaving like "c-w-i". It has the positive side-effect to simplify the work for the project's release liaisons, and for the releases team too. Note: The deliverable types don't need to change, as they mark explicitly what kind of software is delivered. In terms of tagging and releasing, the developers are still encouraged to push features up early, by having them tagged, even if they are not fully polished, on odd months. The difference with "the old way", is that those early features won't be named as "milestones" anymore. They are simple, regular, releases -- their content being recognizable using semver. Release liaisons can continue to iterate during the cycle until the official coordinated release lands, where the official cycle-highlights and release notes will be officially made public by default. Of course, bug fixes can be tagged and pushed at all times, and are now more encouraged than ever. Now we can discuss how will it impact releasing, branching, stabilisation, freezes, cycle highlights. An automatic stopwatch ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ At the middle of each calendar month (whether it's a tick or a tock month), a release will be automatically proposed, and reviewed by the project's releases liaison(s), and by the release team. The work of the releases' liaison is to ensure the commit SHA of the release is significant: the last SHA introducing a feature for odd ("tick", "feature") months before the stabilization period, or the last commit SHA before a new feature lands in the even ("tock", "stabilization") months. The work of the release team is to ensure that the rules are followed, for a consistent behaviour across OpenStack projects, and reject release proposals that don't match the expected. By having some kind of rhythm, and the automation around releasing, we'll reduce the stress of the countdowns. All the odds months will look the same, all the even months will look the same. No exceptions in the way. A cycle stays simple and behaves like clockwork. A project should be allowed to not propose any release if nothing is worth releasing. Projects having nothing to release for the first 4 months will be moved to "independent" on the next cycle, see below. Branching during the cycle ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ We'll continue branching as usual. The coordinated release happens every 6 months currently. In this case, we should branch at 4th month of a cycle, an even (stabilization) month. This makes the newly cut branch already very stable (like we have now), except that it's not because it just went through multiple RCs, but simply because it already has experienced 2 effective months of stabilisation. We used to avoid introducing features at the end of the cycle. This can stay. Developers can start to work on next release starting with month 5. Handle existing stable branches ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ With every other month being used for stabilisation, I would expect more time could be spent on on backporting the bug fixes more actively into stable branches. With more efforts into stable branches, it might become interesting to automatically propose stable branches releases every "tock" months. This would improve on the current situation where some projects don't release their stable branches frequently. Removal of the spec and feature freezes ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ There is no reason to keep the spec and feature freezes, as they were used to prevent large features to get introduced too late in the cycle. Worst case scenario, a large feature gets implemented at the end of the third month. It gives a whole whopping 3 months to get the problem fixed, 1 month without the need of backporting. Cycle highlights ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ They can be written when the release is proposed on the odd months. They will be regularily built by distilling what were the big changes of the month. It's easy to inspect with the release tooling too. We could even improve the new-release tool to help propose them. (Client) library freezes ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Libraries can follow the same 'tick-tock' model. To consume new features of libraries, a project can simply "bump the libraries" versions at the beggining of a feature month, which will consume the last 2-months effort of a library. We could think of automating this. As projects are allowed to tag more frequently than once a month, a library usage could even be "fast tracked" into a service: The PoC change in the library can get released early, and the consumption of it can be directly introduced in the project during the same month. As bumps during 'tock' months would be allowed for bug fixing, it would allow a very fast iterative model. In this model, we would recommend to tag libraries more frequently than every month. With all of this in mind, there is no need to do a 'client library freeze', as the freeze effectively happens by having the 'tock' months. Even if a new feature is introduced in a library during "month 3", we'll have have enough time to consume it in projects and/or fix any eventual major bugs by release time. As a picture is worth more than a thousand words, compare `Ussuri release schedule table <https://releases.openstack.org/ussuri/schedule.html>`_ with the table below. I added in this table the feature/stability work, for emphasis. For a fair comparison between the tables, they should be removed. A cycle is still pretty busy, but the work seems more spread around: +--------------+-------------------------------+---------------------------+ | Month number | OpenStack-wide Events | Project-specific Events | +--------------+-------------------------------+---------------------------+ | 1 | * Feature work | | | | * Removal of deprecations | | | | * Bump external libraries | | | | * Automatic major tag | | +--------------+-------------------------------+---------------------------+ | 2 | * Stability work | | | | * Automatic patch tag | | | | * Current cycle goals | | | | implementation starting | | | | (to be merged month 3) | | +--------------+-------------------------------+---------------------------+ | 3 | * Feature work | * Manila Driver deadlines | | | * Automatic minor tag | * Cinder Driver deadlines | | | * Membership freeze? | | | | * Community goals implemented | | +--------------+-------------------------------+---------------------------+ | 4 | * Stability work | * Extra-ATC deadline | | | * Automatic patch tag | * PTL elections | | | * Branching with patch tag | * Cinder 3rd party CI | | | * TC elections | compliance checkpoint | +--------------+-------------------------------+---------------------------+ | 5 | * Cycle highlights | * Next series goals | | | * Stability work | research and PoC | | | * Automatic patch tag | | | | * Feature work (next branch) | | +--------------+-------------------------------+---------------------------+ | 6 | * Stability work | | | | * Manual patch tag: | | | | Final release | | +--------------+-------------------------------+---------------------------+ Simpler releases for other models --------------------------------- The projects who don't want to follow the 'tick-tock' model (due to its rigidity) would be moved to an "independent" release model. The only difference between the "independent" and the "tick-tock" model is the strictness of the release coordination, for projects which don't need it. This effectively removes the "cycle-trailing" and "tagless" release models. It brings: * Simplified procedures for the release teams (only 2 models remain) * Simplified/uniform tooling that the release team maintains (remove the conditions and special cases) * An improved quality of life, flexibility, and power to "independent" projects. Release would need to make possible for "independent" projects to use the same tooling as the tick-tock coordinated releases. In other words, the release team will need to extend the tooling to allow branching, tagging, and publication of independent (but official OpenStack) projects on PyPI. After all, they are all OpenStack projects, so they should benefit from the ecosystem tools made by the release team. "Independent" projects won't be required to tag during the cycle. Difference between official and unofficial projects --------------------------------------------------- The difference between an official project and an unofficial project would then be the support of the foundation, and the support of the community. The consumers can be ensured that the official projects behave the same way, follow the same goals, and have the same requirements (like PTI, tested distributions, etc.). In other words, ensured about the cohesion. Official projects would also benefit from the marketing power of the foundation. Removal of this policy ---------------------- Assuming OpenStack arrives at a stability focus point, we will be able to easily observe that not many features are shipped during the feature months. This will allow us to remove this policy, while keeping the automation in place. It will then increase the flexibility further, by effectively removing the "tick-tock", and only the "independent" model would remain.

commit_message:
Add octavia-amphora-image-build-live jobs

From time to time DIB changes break Octavia amphora images. Amphora
images also build upon different configurations than the ones in DIB CI
so they would provide additional test coverage to the project.

These two new jobs are primarily meant to help flag regressions
impacting but not limited to Octavia Ubuntu and CentOS amphora images.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/745820/
Change-Id: I0b6b4afb44c15d4ee14d5c3381a3c6edc034a5f7

commit_message:
Configure ceph for glance if multiple stores is enabled

Glance has support to configure multiple stores from Stein release. Recently
support for configuring multiple filesystem stores for glance is added. In
this patch we are configuring ceph if both multiple stores is enabled
using 'GLANCE_ENABLE_MULTIPLE_STORES = True' and ceph is also
enabled.

In order to configure ceph with support to multiple stores using devstack
user need to set below options in local.conf

GLANCE_ENABLE_MULTIPLE_STORES = True
enable_plugin devstack-plugin-ceph https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack-plugin-ceph
ENABLE_CEPH_GLANCE=True

NOTE: These changes are required as soon glance is set to remove single
store support in Victoria cycle.

Change-Id: I210e711aab742e005badc919ec040febb9f45f7f
